  physical_appearance: This is an altar cloth. It has three horizontal panels. The lowest panel features the goddess Dewi Cina Bian Cai Tian
 seated playing the pipa
 a Chinese string instrument. Surrounding her are motifs of animals and figures. The middle panel features more stylized animals amongst foliage. The panels are bordered by fretwork.

  subject_terms_1: deities Peranakan motifs Cantonese cultural diffusion

  subject_terms_2: Altar-cloths Motifs Peranakan (Asian people) Culture diffusion Batik Gods

  subject_terms_3: Religious life and practices Batik

  sgcool_label_text: The goddess Dewi Cina Bian Cai Tian is shown on the lower panel of this tok wi or altar cloth.  This deity is adapted from Fujianese or Cantonese Buddhist folklore
 and is shown seated playing the pipa
 a Chinese string instrument.  Surrounding her are Chinese auspicious symbols
 aquatic animals and dancing celestial beings rendered in European style.  The two panels are bordered by fretwork
 possibly a variant of the banji pattern
 believed by the Chinese to contain talismanic properties.  This tok wi was likely produced in Cirebon
 a northern Javanese coastal town comprising a large population of Chinese.  The ‘cloud’ motif (megamendung) in particular
 is commonly associated with Cirebon.  It is derived from the Chinese auspicious ruyi cloud motif.  These cloths decorated the front of altar tables in homes and in some temples.  Instead of coloured silks or gold thread couchwork in imported Chinese examples
 batik altar cloths were more common in Java.

metadata.title_text: Altar cloth: Dewi Cina Bian Cai Tian goddess Altar cloth with Dewi Cina Bian Cai Tian goddess motif
metadata.physical_appearance: This is an altar cloth. It has three horizontal panels. The lowest panel features the goddess Dewi Cina Bian Cai Tian, seated playing the pipa, a Chinese string instrument. Surrounding her are motifs of animals and figures. The middle panel features more stylized animals amongst foliage. The panels are bordered by fretwork.
metadata.subject_terms_1: deities Peranakan motifs Cantonese cultural diffusion
metadata.subject_terms_2: Altar-cloths Motifs Peranakan (Asian people) Culture diffusion Batik Gods
metadata.sgcool_label_text: The goddess Dewi Cina Bian Cai Tian is shown on the lower panel of this tok wi or altar cloth.  This deity is adapted from Fujianese or Cantonese Buddhist folklore, and is shown seated playing the pipa, a Chinese string instrument.  Surrounding her are Chinese auspicious symbols, aquatic animals and dancing celestial beings rendered in European style.  The two panels are bordered by fretwork, possibly a variant of the banji pattern, believed by the Chinese to contain talismanic properties.  This tok wi was likely produced in Cirebon, a northern Javanese coastal town comprising a large population of Chinese.  The ‘cloud’ motif (megamendung) in particular, is commonly associated with Cirebon.  It is derived from the Chinese auspicious ruyi cloud motif.  These cloths decorated the front of altar tables in homes and in some temples.  Instead of coloured silks or gold thread couchwork in imported Chinese examples, batik altar cloths were more common in Java.
